dt: {bc}to feel respect and approval for (someone or something) {bc}to regard with {d_link|admiration|admiration}

dt.t: … I would {wi}admire{/wi} to know why not …

pt: {sc}regard{/sc} {sc}respect{/sc} {sc}esteem{/sc} {sc}admire{/sc} mean to recognize the worth of a person or thing. {sc}regard{/sc} is a general term that is usually qualified.

pt.t: he is highly {it}regarded{/it} in the profession

pt: {sc}respect{/sc} implies a considered evaluation or estimation.

pt.t: after many years they came to {it}respect{/it} her views

pt: {sc}esteem{/sc} implies greater warmth of feeling accompanying a high valuation.

pt.t: no citizen of the town was more highly {it}esteemed{/it}

pt: {sc}admire{/sc} suggests usually enthusiastic appreciation and often deep affection.

et: borrowed from Middle French {it}admirer,{/it} Latinization of {it}amirer{/it} "to make (little or much) of," borrowed from Latin {it}admīrārī, ammīrārī{/it} "to regard with wonder, show esteem for," from {it}ad-{/it} {et_link|ad-|ad-} + {it}mīrārī{/it} "to be surprised, look with wonder at," derivative of {it}mīrus,{/it} "remarkable, amazing," of uncertain origin
Regarding etymology of Latin {it}mīrus{/it} see note at {et_link|smile:1|smile:1}.
shortdef: to feel respect and approval for (someone or something) : to regard with admiration
